member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgAction`1
member.summary: This is the more complex version of the public result that is produced by the parser.
member.typeparam: Represents the custom argument scaffold type that was passed to the parser.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgAction
member.summary: This is the weakly typed, more complex version of the public result that is produced by the parser.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgAction.Value
member.summary: The instance of your custom scaffold type that the parser generated and parsed.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgAction.ActionArgs
member.summary: If you used the action framework then this will represent the instance of the action specific arguments that were parsed.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgAction.ActionArgsProperty
member.summary: If you used the action framework then this will map to the property that the user specified as the first parameter on the command line.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgAction`1.Invoke
member.summary: This will find the implementation method for your action and invoke it, passing the action specific arguments as a parameter.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgAction`1.ResolveMethod(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Given an action property, finds the method that implements the action.
member.param: The property to resolve

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgAction`1.Args
member.summary: The instance of your custom scaffold type that the parser generated and parsed.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgLongForm
member.summary: An attribute used to define long form aliases for argument names. For example, --log-level instead of -log. It also supports an alternate syntax for providing the values. For example: --log-level=error instead of -log error or /log:error.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgHook
member.summary: An abstract class that you can implement if you want to hook into various parts of the parsing pipeline.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgHook.BeforeParse(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: This hook is called before the parser ever looks at the command line. You can do some preprocessing of the raw string arguments here.
member.param: An object that has useful context. See the documentation of each property for information about when those properties are populated.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgHook.BeforePopulateProperties(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: This hook is called before the arguments defined in a class are populated. For actions (or sub commands) this hook will get called once for the main class and once for the specified action.
member.param: An object that has useful context. See the documentation of each property for information about when those properties are populated.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgHook.BeforePopulateProperty(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: This hook is called before an argument is transformed from a string into a proper type and validated.
member.param: An object that has useful context. See the documentation of each property for information about when those properties are populated.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgHook.AfterPopulateProperty(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: This hook is called after an argument is transformed from a string into a proper type and validated.
member.param: An object that has useful context. See the documentation of each property for information about when those properties are populated.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgHook.AfterPopulateProperties(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: This hook is called after the arguments defined in a class are populated. For actions (or sub commands) this hook will get called once for the main class and once for the specified action.
member.param: An object that has useful context. See the documentation of each property for information about when those properties are populated.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgHook.BeforeParsePriority
member.summary: The priority of the BeforeParse hook. Higher numbers execute first.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgHook.BeforePopulatePropertiesPriority
member.summary: The priority of the BeforePopulateProperties hook. Higher numbers execute first.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgHook.BeforePopulatePropertyPriority
member.summary: The priority of the BeforePopulateProperty hook. Higher numbers execute first.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgHook.AfterPopulatePropertyPriority
member.summary: The priority of the AfterPopulateProperty hook. Higher numbers execute first.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgHook.AfterPopulatePropertiesPriority
member.summary: The priority of the AfterPopulateProperties hook. Higher numbers execute first.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext
member.summary: Context that is passed to your hook. Different parts of the context will be available depending on which part of the pipeline you're hooking into.

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext.CmdLineArgs
member.summary: The command line arguments that were passed to the Args class. This is always available and you can modify it in the BeforeParse hook at your own risk.

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext.ArgumentValue
member.summary:
The string value that was specified for the current property. This will align with the value of ArgHook.Property.
This is not available during BeforePopulateProperties or AfterPopulateProperties.

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext.RevivedProperty
member.summary: This is the value of the current property after it has been converted into its proper .NET type. It is only available to the AfterPopulateProperty hook.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext.Property
member.summary: The current property being operating on. This is not available during BeforePopulateProperties or AfterPopulateProperties.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext.Args
member.summary: This is the instance of your argument class. The amount that it is populated will depend on how far along in the pipeline the parser is.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext.ParserData
member.summary: The raw parser data. This is not available to the BeforeParse hook. It may be useful for you to look at, but you should rarely have to change the values. Modify the content of this at your own risk.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgLongForm.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgLongForm attirbute using the given long form string.
member.param: The long form value. You can provide the two dashes in this string or not. The --long-form pattern will enforced at runtime either way.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgLongForm.BeforeParse(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: Finds instances of the long form alias on the command line and replaces it with a standard property specification.
member.param: The context that has access to the command line args and the target property.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgReviverAttribute
member.summary: The attribute used when you want to create an arg reviver. You should put this on public static methods that take 2 string parameters (the first represents the name of the property, the second represents the string value and the return type is the type that you are reviving (or converting) the string into.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgReviverAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new ArgReviverAttribute

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgActionType
member.summary: Use this attribute if your action implementation methods are defined in a type other than the type being passed to Args.ParseAction() or Args.InvokeAction().

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgActionType.#ctor(System.Type)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgActionType attribute given the type that contains the action implementation.
member.param: The type that implements your action methods.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgActionType.ActionType
member.summary: The type that implements your action methods.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgStyleAttribute
member.summary: Obsolete - Don't use this. Both the -name value and /name:value styles are now both supported automatically.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgStyleAttribute.#ctor(PowerArgs.ArgStyle)
member.summary: Obsolete - Don't use this. Both the -name value and /name:value styles are now both supported automatically.
member.param: obsolete

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgStyleAttribute.Style
member.summary: Obsolete - Don't use this. Both the -name value and /name:value styles are now both supported automatically.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgIgnoreCase
member.summary: Use this argument on your class or property to enforce case sensitivity. By default, case is ignored.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgIgnoreCase.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a new ArgIgnoreCase attribute.
member.param: Whether or not to ignore case

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgIgnoreCase.IgnoreCase
member.summary: Flag to set whether or not case is ignored.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgEnforceCase
member.summary: Use this argument on your class or property to enforce case sensitivity. By default, case is ignored.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgEnforceCase.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new ArgEnforceCase attribute.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgShortcutPolicy
member.summary: An enum to represent argument shortcut policies

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgShortcutPolicy.NoShortcut
member.summary: Pass this value to the ArgShortcut attribute's constructor to indicate that the given property does not support a shortcut.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgShortcut
member.summary: Use this attribute to override the shortcut that PowerArgs automatically assigns to each property.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgShortcut.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgShortcut attribute with a specified value.
member.param: The value of the new shortcut.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgShortcut.#ctor(PowerArgs.ArgShortcutPolicy)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgShortcut using the given policy

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgShortcut.GetShortcut(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Get the shortcut value given a property info object. This can only be called after one of the Args methods has parsed the parent type at least once. Otherwise you will get an InvalidArgDefinitionException.k
member.param: The property whose shortcut you want to get.
member.returns: The shortcut for the property

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgShortcut.Shortcut
member.summary: The shortcut for the given property

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgIgnoreAttribute
member.summary: Use this attribute if you want PowerArgs to ignore a property completely.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgPosition
member.summary: Use this attribute if you want users to be able to specify an argument without specifying the name, but rather by it's position on the command line. All positioned arguments must come before any named arguments. Zero '0' represents the first position. If you are using the Action framework then subcommands must start at position 1.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgPosition.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgPositionAttribute
member.param: The expected position of this argument

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgPosition.Position
member.summary: The expected position of this argument

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgDescription
member.summary: Use this attribute to describe your argument property. This will show up in the auto generated usage documentation.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgDescription.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgDescription attribute.
member.param: A brief description of your argument property.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgDescription.Description
member.summary: A brief description of your argument property.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgExample
member.summary: Use this attribute to provide an example of how to use your program.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgExample.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgExample class
member.param: The example command line.
A brief description of what this example does.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgExample.Example
member.summary: The example command line.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgExample.Description
member.summary: A brief description of what this example does.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.StickyArg
member.summary: A useful arg hook that will store the last used value for an argument and repeat it the next time.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.StickyArg.#ctor
member.summary: Marks a property as a sticky arg. Use the default location to store sticky arguments (AppData/Roaming/PowerArgs/EXE_NAME.txt)

member.name: M:PowerArgs.StickyArg.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Marks a property as a sticky arg. Use the provided location to store sticky arguments (AppData/Roaming/PowerArgs/EXE_NAME.txt)

member.name: M:PowerArgs.StickyArg.BeforePopulateProperty(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: If the user didn't specify a value on the command line then the StickyArg will try to load the last used value.
member.param: Used to see if the property was specified.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.StickyArg.AfterPopulateProperty(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: If the given property has a non null value then that value is persisted for the next use.
member.param: Used to see if the property was specified.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.DefaultValueAttribute
member.summary: Use this attribute to set the default value for a parameter. Note that this only works for simple types since only compile time constants can be passed to an attribute.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.DefaultValueAttribute.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates a new DefaultValueAttribute with the given value. Note that the value will get converted to a string and then fed into the parser to be revived.
member.param: The default value for the property

member.name: M:PowerArgs.DefaultValueAttribute.BeforePopulateProperty(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: Before the property is revived and validated, if the user didn't specify a value, then substitue the default value.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.DefaultValueAttribute.Value
member.summary: The default value that was specified on the attribute. Note that the value will get converted to a string and then fed into the parser to be revived.

member.summary: Create a ConsoleString given an initial text value and optional color info.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ConsoleString.Empty
member.summary: Represents an empty string. You will get a new instance each time you access this property.

member.summary: The length of the string.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.Args
member.summary: The main entry point for PowerArgs that includes the public parsing functions such as Parse, ParseAction, and InvokeAction.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.Args.ParseAction``1(System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of T and populates it's properties based on the given arguments. If T correctly implements the heuristics for Actions (or sub commands) then the complex property that represents the options of a sub command are also populated.
member.param: The command line arguments to parse
member.returns: The raw result of the parse with metadata about the specified action.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.Args.ParseAction(System.Type,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the given type and populates it's properties based on the given arguments. If the type correctly implements the heuristics for Actions (or sub commands) then the complex property that represents the options of a sub command are also populated.
member.param: The argument scaffold type.
The command line arguments to parse
member.returns: The raw result of the parse with metadata about the specified action.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.Args.InvokeAction``1(System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of T and populates it's properties based on the given arguments. T must correctly implement the heuristics for Actions (or sub commands) because this method will not only detect the action specified on the command line, but will also find and execute the method that implements the action.
member.typeparam: The argument scaffold type that must properly implement at least one action.
member.param: The command line arguments to parse
member.returns: The raw result of the parse with metadata about the specified action. The action is executed before returning.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.Args.Parse``1(System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of T and populates it's properties based on the given arguments.
member.param: The command line arguments to parse
member.returns: A new instance of T with all of the properties correctly populated

member.name: M:PowerArgs.Args.Parse(System.Type,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the given type and populates it's properties based on the given arguments.
member.param: The argument scaffold type
The command line arguments to parse
member.returns: A new instance of the given type with all of the properties correctly populated

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgStyle
member.summary: Obsolete, both the -name value and /name:value styles are supported automatically.

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgStyle.PowerShell
member.summary: Obsolete, both the -name value and /name:value styles are supported automatically.

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgStyle.SlashColon
member.summary: Obsolete, both the -name value and /name:value styles are supported automatically.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ParseResult
member.summary: The raw parse result that contains the dictionary of values that were parsed

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ParseResult.ExplicitParameters
member.summary: Dictionary of values that were either in the format -key value or /key:value on the command line.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ParseResult.ImplicitParameters
member.summary:
Dictionary of values that were implicitly specified by position where the key is the position (e.g. 0) and the value is the actual parameter value.
Example command line: Program.exe John Smith
John would be an implicit parameter at position 0. Smith would be an implicit parameter at position 1.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.UsageHook
member.summary: An attribute used to hook into the usage generation process and influence the content that is written.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.UsageHook.BeforeGenerateUsage(PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo)
member.summary: This hook gets called when the property it is attached to is having its usage generated. You can override this method and manipulate the properties of the given usage info object.
member.param: An object that you can use to manipulate the usage output.

member.name: E:PowerArgs.UsageHook.HookExecuting
member.summary: An event you can subscribe to in the case where you created your hook in running code rather than as a declarative attribute.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo
member.summary: A class that represents usage info to be written to the console.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.#ctor(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Generate a new info instance given a reflected property.
member.param: The property to use to seed the usage info

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.Name
member.summary: The name that will be written as part of the usage.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.Aliases
member.summary: Aliases for this argument that will be honored by the parser. This includes shortcuts and long form aliases, but can be extended further.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.IsRequired
member.summary: Indicates that the argument is required.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.Type
member.summary: The friendly type name that will be displayed to the user.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.Position
member.summary: The expected position of the argument, or null if not a positioning is not supported for the given argument.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.Description
member.summary: The description that will be written as part of the usage.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.Ignore
member.summary: If set to true, the argument usage will not be written.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.IsAction
member.summary: True if this is the "Action" property

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.IsActionArgs
member.summary: True if this represents a nested action argument property

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgumentUsageInfo.Property
member.summary: The reflected property that this info object represents

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgUsage
member.summary: A helper class that generates usage documentation for your command line arguments given a custom argument scaffolding type.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgUsage.RegisterHook(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo,PowerArgs.UsageHook)
member.summary: Registers a usage hook for the given property.
member.param: The property to hook into or null to hook into all properties.
The hook implementation.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgUsage.GetUsage``1(System.String)
member.summary: Generates usage documentation for the given argument scaffold type.
member.param: The name of your program or null if you want PowerArgs to automatically detect it.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgUsage.GetStyledUsage``1(System.String)
member.summary: Generates color styled usage documentation for the given argument scaffold type.
member.param: The name of your program or null if you want PowerArgs to automatically detect it.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgException
member.summary: An exception that should be thrown when the error condition is caused because of bad user input.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgException given a user friendly message
member.param: A user friendly message.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgException given a user friendly message
member.param: A user friendly message.
The inner exception that caused the problem

member.name: T:PowerArgs.InvalidArgDefinitionException
member.summary: An exception that should be thrown when the error condition is caused by an improperly formed argument scaffold type. For example if the user specified the same shortcut value for more than one property.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.InvalidArgDefinitionException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new InvalidArgDefinitionException given a message.
member.param: An error message.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.InvalidArgDefinitionException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Creates a new InvalidArgDefinitionException given a message.
member.param: An error message.
The inner exception that caused the problem

member.name: T:PowerArgs.GroupedRegexArg
member.summary: An abstract class that lets you create custom argument types that match a regular expression. The class also makes it easy to extract named groups from the regular expression for use by your application.

member.name: F:PowerArgs.GroupedRegexArg.exactMatch
member.summary: The match that exactly matches the given regular expression

member.name: M:PowerArgs.GroupedRegexArg.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new grouped regular expression argument instance.
member.param: The regular expression to enforce
The user input that was provided
An error message to show in the case of a non match

member.name: M:PowerArgs.GroupedRegexArg.Group(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: A helper function you can use to group a particular regular expression.
member.param: Your regular expression that you would like to put in a group.
The name of the group that you can use to extract the group value later.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.GroupedRegexArg.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the value of the regex group from the exact match.
member.param: The name of the group to lookup

member.name: P:PowerArgs.GroupedRegexArg.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the value of the regex group from the exact match.
member.param: The index of the group to lookup

member.name: T:PowerArgs.USPhoneNumber
member.summary: An example of a custom type that uses regular expressions to extract values from the command line and implements an ArgReviver to transform the text input into a complex type. This class represents a US phone number.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.USPhoneNumber.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a phone number object from a string

member.name: M:PowerArgs.USPhoneNumber.ToString
member.summary: Gets the default string representation of the phone number in the format '1-(aaa)-bbb-cccc'.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.USPhoneNumber.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Formats the phone number as a string.
member.param: Use '{aaa}' for the area code, use {bbb} for the first grouping, and use {cccc} for the second grouping.
member.returns: A formatted phone number string

member.name: M:PowerArgs.USPhoneNumber.Revive(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Custom PowerArgs reviver that converts a string parameter into a custom phone number
member.param: The name of the argument (not used)
The value specified on the command line
member.returns: A USPhoneNumber object based on the user input

member.name: P:PowerArgs.USPhoneNumber.AreaCode
member.summary: The three digit area code of the phone number.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.USPhoneNumber.FirstDigits
member.summary: The three digit first segment of the phone number

member.name: P:PowerArgs.USPhoneNumber.SecondDigits
member.summary: The four digit second segment of the phone number.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgValidator
member.summary: An abstract class that all validators should extend to validate user input from the command line.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgValidator.Validate(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary:
Most validators should just override this method. It ONLY gets called if the user specified the given argument on the command line, meaning you will never get a null for 'arg'.
If you want your validator to run even if the user did not specify the argument on the command line (for example if you were building something like [ArgRequired] then you should do 3 things.
1 - Override the boolean ImplementsValidateAlways property so that it returns true 2 - Override the ValidateAlways() method instead 3 - Don't override the Validate() method since it will no longer be called
member.param: The value specified on the command line. If the user specified the property name, but not a value then arg will equal string.Empty. The value will never be null.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgValidator.ValidateAlways(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo,System.String@)
member.summary: Always validates the given property, even if it was not specified by the user (arg will be null in this case). If you override this method then you should also override ImplementsValidateAlways so it returns true.
member.param: The property that the attribute was placed on.
The value specified on the command line or null if the user didn't actually specify a value for the property. If the user specified the property name, but not a value then arg will equal string.Empty

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgValidator.Priority
member.summary: Determines the order in which validators are executed. Higher numbers execute first.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgValidator.ImplementsValidateAlways
member.summary:
If implemented in a derived class then ValidateAlways will be called for each property, even if that property wasn't specified by the user on the command line. In this case the value will always be null. This is useful for implementing validators such as [ArgRequired].
By default, the Validate(string,ref string) method is called unless a validator opts into ValidateAlways

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgExistingFile
member.summary: Validates that if the user specifies a value for a property that the value represents a file that exists as determined by System.IO.File.Exists(file).

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgExistingFile.Validate(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Validates that the given file exists and cleans up the argument so that the application has access to the full path.
member.param: the name of the property being populated. This validator doesn't do anything with it.
The value specified on the command line

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgExistingDirectory
member.summary: Validates that if the user specifies a value for a property that the value represents a directory that exists as determined by System.IO.Directory.Exists(directory).

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgExistingDirectory.Validate(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Validates that the given directory exists and cleans up the argument so that the application has access to the full path.
member.param: the name of the property being populated. This validator doesn't do anything with it.
The value specified on the command line

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgRange
member.summary: Validates that the value is a number between the min and max (both inclusive) specified

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgRange.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgRange validator.
member.param: The minimum value (inclusive)
The maximum value (inclusive by default, set MaxIsExclusive to true to override)

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgRange.Validate(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Validates that the value is a number between the min and max (both inclusive) specifie
member.param: the name of the property being populated. This validator doesn't do anything with it.
The value specified on the command line

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgRange.MaxIsExclusive
member.summary: Set to true if your max is exclusive. This value is false by default.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgRequired
member.summary: Validates that the user actually provided a value for the given property on the command line.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgRequired.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new ArgRequired attribute.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgRequired.ValidateAlways(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo,System.String@)
member.summary: Validates that the user actually specified a value and optionally prompts them when it is missing.
member.param: The property being populated. This validator doesn't do anything with it.
The value specified on the command line or null if it wasn't specified

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgRequired.ImplementsValidateAlways
member.summary: Determines whether or not the validator should run even if the user doesn't specify a value on the command line. This value is always true for this validator.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.ArgRequired.PromptIfMissing
member.summary: If you set this to true and the user didn't specify a value then the command line will prompt the user for the value.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ArgRegex
member.summary: Performs regular expression validation on a property.

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgRegex.regex
member.summary: The regular expression to match

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgRegex.errorMessage
member.summary: A prefix for the error message to show in the case of a match.

member.name: F:PowerArgs.ArgRegex.exactMatch
member.summary: The exact match that was found.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgRegex.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new ArgRegex validator.
member.param: The regular expression that requires an exact match to be valid
A prefix for the error message to show in the case of a match.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ArgRegex.Validate(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Validates that the given arg exactly matches the regular expression provided.
member.param: the name of the property being populated. This validator doesn't do anything with it.
The value specified on the command line.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.Query
member.summary: A hook you can use to easily query a data source. See an example here: https://github.com/adamabdelhamed/PowerArgs#data-source-queries

member.name: M:PowerArgs.Query.#ctor(System.Type,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new query hook given a data source type and optional reference assemblies.
member.param: Your data source implementation. he query will create a new instance of this type and use a property that matches the property name of the PowerArgs property this attribute is on in order to get the data.
The names (if in the GAC) or full paths to assemblies you would like to include. We will automatically add dlls in your bin folder.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.Query.AfterPopulateProperties(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: After PowerArgs does most of its work this hook looks for string properties on the parsed object called Skip, Take, Where, OrderBy, and OrderByDescending. These properties are used to construct a linq query that is dynamically compiled and executed against the provided data source.
member.param: The context used to detect the query parameters.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.Query.DataSourceType
member.summary: Your data source implementation. The query will create a new instance of this type and use a property that matches the property name of the PowerArgs property this attribute is on in order to get the data.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.Resources
member.summary: A strongly-typed resource class, for looking up localized strings, etc.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.Resources.ResourceManager
member.summary: Returns the cached ResourceManager instance used by this class.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.Resources.Culture
member.summary: Overrides the current thread's CurrentUICulture property for all resource lookups using this strongly typed resource class.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.Resources.QueryTemplate
T:PowerArgs.SecureStringArgument
member.summary: A PowerArgs argument type that can be used to accept user input without that input appearing on the command line. It uses secure strings under the hood.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.SecureStringArgument.ConvertToNonsecureString
member.summary: Converts the underlying secure string to a regular string.
member.returns: A normal string representation of the user's input.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.SecureStringArgument.SecureString
member.summary: The secure string value. The first time your code accesses this property is when the user will be presented with the secure input prompt.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.TabCompletion
member.summary: A hook that takes over the command line and provides tab completion for known strings when the user presses the tab key.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.TabCompletion.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new tab completion hook.
member.param: When this indicator is the only argument the user specifies that triggers the hook to enhance the command prompt. By default, the indicator is the empty string.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.TabCompletion.#ctor(System.Type,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new tab completion hook given a custom tab completion implementation.
member.param: A type that implements ITabCompletionSource such as SimpleTabCompletionSource
When this indicator is the only argument the user specifies that triggers the hook to enhance the command prompt. By default, the indicator is the empty string.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.TabCompletion.BeforeParse(PowerArgs.ArgHook.HookContext)
member.summary: Before PowerArgs parses the args, this hook inspects the command line for the indicator and if found takes over the command line and provides tab completion.
member.param: The context used to inspect the command line arguments.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.TabCompletion.ClearHistory
member.summary: Clears all history saved on disk

member.name: P:PowerArgs.TabCompletion.HistoryToSave
member.summary: If this is > 0 then PowerArgs will save this many previous executions of the command line to your application data folder. Users can then access the history by pressing arrow up or down from the enhanced command prompt.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.TabCompletion.HistoryFileName
member.summary: The location of the history file name (AppData/PowerArgs/EXE_NAME.TabCompletionHistory.txt

member.name: P:PowerArgs.TabCompletion.ExeName
member.summary: The name of your program (leave null and PowerArgs will try to detect it automatically)

member.name: T:PowerArgs.ITabCompletionSource
member.summary: An interface used to implement custom tab completion logic.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.ITabCompletionSource.TryComplete(System.Boolean,System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: PowerArgs will call this method if it has enhanced the command prompt and the user presses tab. You should use the text the user has types so far to determine if there is a completion you'd like to make. If you find a completion then you should assign it to the completion variable and return true.
member.param: Indicates if shift was being pressed
The text token that the user has typed before pressing tab.
The variable that you should assign the completed string to if you find a match.
member.returns: True if you completed the string, false otherwise.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.MultiTabCompletionSource
member.summary: An aggregate tab completion source that cycles through it's inner sources looking for matches.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.MultiTabCompletionSource.#ctor(PowerArgs.ITabCompletionSource[])
member.summary: Create a new MultiTabCompletionSource given an array of sources.
member.param: The sources to wrap

member.name: M:PowerArgs.MultiTabCompletionSource.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{PowerArgs.ITabCompletionSource})
member.summary: Create a new MultiTabCompletionSource given an IEnumerable of sources.
member.param: The sources to wrap

member.name: M:PowerArgs.MultiTabCompletionSource.TryComplete(System.Boolean,System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Iterates over the wrapped sources looking for a match
member.param: Indicates if shift was being pressed
The text token that the user has typed before pressing tab.
The variable that you should assign the completed string to if you find a match.

member.name: T:PowerArgs.SimpleTabCompletionSource
member.summary: A simple tab completion source implementation that looks for matches over a set of pre-determined strings.

member.name: M:PowerArgs.SimpleTabCompletionSource.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Creates a new completion source given an enumeration of string candidates

member.name: M:PowerArgs.SimpleTabCompletionSource.TryComplete(System.Boolean,System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Iterates through the candidates to try to find a match. If there are multiple possible matches it supports cycling through tem as the user continually presses tab.
member.param: Indicates if shift was being pressed
The text token that the user has typed before pressing tab.
The variable that you should assign the completed string to if you find a match.

member.name: P:PowerArgs.SimpleTabCompletionSource.MinCharsBeforeCyclingBegins
member.summary: Require that the user type this number of characters before the source starts cycling through ambiguous matches. The default is 3.
